node.title: Singular shape tensor in Peridynamics
node.bodyText:
I'm a newbie, but I'm currently experiencing the following problems.What can I do if the following problems occur? Thank you.
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "strain", of type "ComputePlaneSmallStrainNOSPD".
Singular shape tensor is detected in ComputeStrainBaseNOSPD! Use SingularShapeTensorEliminatorUserObjectPD to avoid singular shape tensor!

I've tried everything I can, but to no avail, it seems that I can only modify the number of grids to work properly. This is an example from the most common tests, just increasing the number of meshes, but this problem occurs. Is there any other solution?
@hchen139 do you have any suggestions for this user?
Is this an issue with uniform refinement?
I don't think PD uses any refinement. Proper use of the 'SingularShapeTensorEliminatorUserObjectPD' should be able to avoid the singularity issue.
I had a similar issue a while ago. The problem was that the SingularShapeTensorEliminatorUserObjectPD was not the first user object executed. Maybe this helps #24239

node.title: Double inner product of two RankTwotensor
node.bodyText:
Hi moose community,
I would like to ask what's the command for the double inner product of two RankTwotensor.
Here I want to calculate the plastic work increment _plastic_work_incr = _stress_old[_qp] : _plastic_strain_incr[_qp], where _plastic_work_incr is a scalar and _stress_old and _plastic_strain_incr are RankTwotensor.
Thanks very much!
_stress_old[_qp].doubleContraction(_plastic_strain_incr[_qp])
Thanks!

node.title: Use `use_displaced_mesh` in `StressDivergenceTensors`

node.bodyText: @recuero @hugary1995

The first one is whether the gradient of the test function is taken w.r.t. the current or reference configuration?

The gradient is wrt the current configuration if use_displaced_mesh = true, wrt reference configuration otherwise.

The second question ... However, from the code snippet below, it seems that such switch is only applicable when the mesh dimension is less than 3.

That's not true.

Furthermore, adding use_displaced_mesh = true to the master action results in an error.

The action will set the appropriate configuration for you based on other parameters. Hence the error.

My last question is, therefore, which stress should we feed the StressDivergenceTensors? In other words, when we are defining a new material, which stress should be the final result?

The Cauchy stress.

Thank you so much for the answers!
I have a further question. Could you help suggest which setting in the input file might conflict with use_displaced_mesh = true? The input file is listed pasted.
[Mesh]
  [generated_mesh]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    elem_type = HEX8
    dim = 3
    nx = 1
    ny = 1
    nz = 1
    xmin = 0.0
    xmax = 1.0
    ymin = 0.0
    ymax = 1.0
    zmin = 0.0
    zmax = 1.0
  []
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [all]
    strain = FINITE
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
    decomposition_method = EigenSolution
    #use_displaced_mesh = true
    add_variables = true
    use_finite_deform_jacobian = true
    volumetric_locking_correction = false
    generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_yy stress_zz stress_xy stress_xz'
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteDruckerPragerStress
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
    cohesion_c = 1e+7        # [Pa]
    friction_phi = 0.5236    # [rad]
    dilatancy_psi = 0        # [rad]
    circle_choice = Inner
    hardening_n = 1e+15
    lame_lambda = 8.0769e+9  # [Pa]
    lame_mu = 5.3846e+9      # [Pa]
    elasticity_model = Hencky
    etol = 1e-10
    ptol = 1e-10
    ftol = 1e-10
  []
  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    lambda = 8.0769e+9        # [Pa]
    shear_modulus = 5.3846e+9 # [Pa]
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [top]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = top
    function = '0.001 * t'
  []
  [bottom_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0.0
  []
  [bottom_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0.0
  []
  [bottom_z]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0.0
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
   type = SMP
   full=true
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  dt=1
  end_time=10
  #nl_abs_tol = 1e-8
[]

[Outputs]
  [exodus]
    type = Exodus
  []
[]

[Debug]
  show_material_props = true
[]

Also, since the algorithm I have is based on the total strain not the incremental strain, I added displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z' in [Materials/stress], will it possibly be inconsistent with ComputeFiniteStrain?
And one last general question on the Executioner. In the output, there is usually a linear solver nested within a nonlinear one. I can understand that the nonlinear solver is to solve for displacement from the global stiffness matrix and the right hand side. What is the linear solver for? I saw from previous discussion that the convergence issue is usually with the nonlinear solver and not the linear one and am having the same issue myself. What could possibly cause that?

I have a further question. Could you help suggest which setting in the input file might conflict with use_displaced_mesh = true? The input file is listed pasted.

What do you mean by "conflict with use_displaced_mesh = true"? Where and why do you want to manipulate use_displaced_mesh yourself. We typically advise against that.

Also, since the algorithm I have is based on the total strain not the incremental strain, I added displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z' in [Materials/stress], will it possibly be inconsistent with ComputeFiniteStrain

This question along with the previous one are very difficult to answer in general. Please clarify:

Are you dealing with small deformation or large deformation?
If large deformation, which strain/stress measures are you working with?
Why do you insist on computing the stress on the deformed configuration?


And one last general question on the Executioner. In the output, there is usually a linear solver nested within a nonlinear one. I can understand that the nonlinear solver is to solve for displacement from the global stiffness matrix and the right hand side. What is the linear solver for?

No, the linear system is the traditional K u = f taught in old-school engineer classes. For a general nonlinear system, R(u) = 0, you need to iteratively update it (hence the nonlinear loop). See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton%27s_method

I saw from previous discussion that the convergence issue is usually with the nonlinear solver and not the linear one and am having the same issue myself. What could possibly cause that?

This is again very difficult to answer because the cause of convergence issues can vary dramatically from problem to problem. The troubleshooting page should be a good starting point: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/failed_solves.html

node.title: Assigning boundary names for subdomains created in a mesh
node.bodyText:
How to give boundary conditions (top, bottom, left and right) for the subdomain  blocks too ? E.g. for a mesh shown below, Is it possible to assign boundary names to the sides of the subdomains too? I am not sure if "SideSetsFromBoundingBoxGenerator" is the option to do this. I tried my best to find reading documentation and forum here and I couldn't.
[Mesh]
[air_block]
type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
dim = 2
nx = 100
ny = 100
xmax = 0.04
ymax = 0.1
[]
[water_block]
type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
input = air_block
block_id = 1
bottom_left = '0 0 0'
top_right = '0.04 0.039 0'
[]

For something simple like left / bottom etc boundaries you can work with that one but also with those generators
SidesetFromNormals
SidesetsaroundSubdomain
ParsedGenerateSideset

Thanks I will try. I want to give boundary conditions for top of both the air_block and water_block, and I assume, if I mentioned bottom, it naturally be referring the bottom of water_block and not the air_block. Isnt it?
You ll have to work with the parameters of these objects. The defaults, unless there s a block parameter, is to consider the whole mesh

node.title: meshing in porous flow module
node.bodyText:
Hello moose community,
I am new comer to moose and i would like to use porous flow to simulation the injection of CO2 in brine-saturated reservoir. I found all the geometry/meshes in the tutorials are horizontal and regular geometry. I am kindly wondering if it possible to include some titling meshed geometry-- a case where the mesh has a fold- (or dome-) shape? Can we do that in moose or one needs a third-party software?
thanks and I will much appreciate your help in advance.
Best, Lupeom

Hi Lupeom,
Almost all of the PorousFlow tests and examples use MOOSE's inbuilt meshing capability.  While that is suitable for highly idealised situations, you almost always need something more sophisticated when dealing with real geology and hydrostratigraphy, as you have found.
You will need to use an external meshing software package.  I have built many models of the subsurface, and have found that meshing often takes a significant fraction of the time spent modelling, so don't think that meshing is a trivial, quick task!
Some people can get Cubit free, while others (like me) have to pay lots of $$$ for it.  There is a "sibling" product called coreform that has free aspects.  Many MOOSE people use the excellent and free tool called gmsh that works well for PorousFlow type of problems.  If you are going to be in this field for many years, you might like to make your own mesh-translation tools (between different formatting) and mesh-building tools, probably based on the exodus or VTK libraries, since none of the aforementioned packages easily handle subsurface hydrostratigraphy with faults and so on.
a
Coreform Cubit is the commercial version of Cubit: https://cubit.sandia.gov/licensing.html

@lupeom
As mentioned above, we (Coreform) provide a non-commercial license for Coreform Cubit.  It's fully-functional but is limited to exporting 50k elements.  If this limit is too restricting, contact us and we can discuss temporarily removing this restriction (especially if it's for a dissertation or thesis).  If you're interested in the Coreform Cubit route, you can find Cubit tutorials on our website and you can post Cubit-specific questions on our forum for the Cubit community to answer.

Can I apply for the temporary removal of the export restriction? I am writing a research paper on numerical simulations.
Thanks!
Thanks so much @WilkAndy and @GregVernon  for your valuable comments, so much appreciated.

@lupeom you could also try our open source meshing generator (look here #16537 (comment)). It has been developed for similar applications as those you are interested and it is fully Moose compatibile. Let me know if you would have any questions
Thanks so much @mcacace, very interesting.

node.title: show_var_residual for variables of type LAGRANGE_VEC
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Team,
We are using MALAMUTE for melt pool simulations and needed to study how the residuals vary in response to random perturbations to the solution. We are using show_var_residual in the Debug block for dumping the residuals to the Exodus file. It works well for scalar variables like temperature and pressure but gives error for vector variables like velocity. For instance, if we use the following:
[Variables]
  [velocity]
    family = LAGRANGE_VEC
  []
[]
[Debug]
  show_var_residual =  'velocity'
[]

It gives the error: "No standard variable named velocity found. Did you specify a vector variable when you meant to specify a standard variable"
We tried using specific components like show_var_residual =  'velocity_x', but that leads to a segmentation fault.
Is there a workaround for this issue? We would appreciate any help on this.
Thanks,
Anant

Hello
We have no implemented variable residual debugging for vector variables.
You ll want to modify the DebugResidualAux to make it work for vector variables
Guillaume

node.title: Generate new boundary (sideset) from current boundary
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I am trying to find a way to generate a new boundary from an existing boundary. To be specific, I want to 'cut' part of the exist boundary:

Is there an easy way to do so?

Hello
If you know a good analytical expression for it, like "x > 3.2" for example, then you can use the ParsedGenerateSideset
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/ParsedGenerateSideset.html
Guillaume
Can I use old boundary with the expression "x > 3.2" to generate a new boundary with ParsedGenerateSideset?

unfortunately not.
It's definitely something we're missing
I feel like it shouldn't be too hard to add an option included_boundaries similar to included_subdomians. Let me try to add it
Functionality was added

node.title: Gas mixing with immobile water in PorousFlow module
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
Hope you are doing well.
I wanted to simulate a 2-phase system of immobile water and two gases. At first gases are separated and then they get mixed. I am using PorousFlow module, and the problem is that I cannot define fluid properties for each component, and it only accepts for phases. How I can define material property for each gas in my system since they are after all in the same phase. I was wondering if can be done with PorousFlow.
Thanks,
Sina

Dear all,
Hope you are doing well.
I was wondering if there is a solution for this or if not how the code should be modified. Thanks again for your insight.
Sina
@cpgr
@WilkAndy @cpgr

node.title: Eigen strain function of nodal coordinate
node.bodyText: Hello, I want to use a nodal coordinate dependent eigen strain in my phase field model (e^(-kx) where s is the position along x axis. Kindly guide me about how to access the nodal coordinate

Hello
I m not sure what you mean here.
You need to get a coordinate from a mesh that meets a certain criterion?
Guillaume

oh in your eigenstrain model (a material property) you want to access the local position?
Well first, we do not have nodal material properties
We could develop them using the functor system if needed, though there might be a delay there
